metadata.name: The Restoration Scheme: Shape Observation #4
metadata.description:
â€œShape Observationâ€ is the first episode of â€œThe Restoration Schemeâ€ Series. The work was based on Staghorn Coral. 

Living on the land, we have few opportunities to see corals in real life.
Most of my impressions of corals come from photos and illustrations.
So I think the first person who discovers coral must be stunned by its shape and color.
They may paint hundreds of pictures like this.

â€”â€”

â€œThe Restoration Schemeâ€ Series

Itâ€™s a virtual action extended from the coral restoration plan led by Delta Electronics Foundation from Taiwan, consisting of five generative corals. Each of them was based on five different species of coral as the theme.

If collectors mint virtual corals, Delta Electronics Foundation will drop coral seedlings collectively in the sea. 

The project is powered by FAB DAO (Formosa Art Bank). The split will donate to the local organization from Taiwan dedicated to the coral restoration scheme.

â€”â€”

About Delta 

Climate change is causing irreversible impacts. Coral reefs, known for their rich biodiversity and the capability to nourish a quarter of marine life, are at the forefront of the crisis. 

Also known as "tropical rainforests" in the sea, coral reefs have experienced fiveÂ massÂ bleachingÂ events in the past five years. Once global warming exceeds the 2ËšC thresholds, it's likely that 99% of coral reefs will die off worldwide.

In addition to launching a coral restoration initiative along the northeast coast of Taiwan, Delta Electronics Foundation collaborates with Asia University to host "Earth Pulsing: Nurturing Life Exhibition" and releases the first art NFT featuring coral restoration. Through these actions, we hope to evoke public awareness of ecological issues. 

For more information, please visit https://delta50.deltaww.com/initiative/sea.html

â€”â€”

Features
Iterations: 1 ~ 4
Tail: round, sharp
Feathering: yes, no
Color yes, no
Paper: normal, colored, white
Weight: regular, thin, bold
Special: -
Growth Speed: regular, slow, super slow

double click or press 's' to save as an image

made with p5.js

metadata.name: The Restoration Scheme: Shape Observation #10
metadata.description:
â€œShape Observationâ€ is the first episode of â€œThe Restoration Schemeâ€ Series. The work was based on Staghorn Coral. 

Living on the land, we have few opportunities to see corals in real life.
Most of my impressions of corals come from photos and illustrations.
So I think the first person who discovers coral must be stunned by its shape and color.
They may paint hundreds of pictures like this.

â€”â€”

â€œThe Restoration Schemeâ€ Series

Itâ€™s a virtual action extended from the coral restoration plan led by Delta Electronics Foundation from Taiwan, consisting of five generative corals. Each of them was based on five different species of coral as the theme.

If collectors mint virtual corals, Delta Electronics Foundation will drop coral seedlings collectively in the sea. 

The project is powered by FAB DAO (Formosa Art Bank). The split will donate to the local organization from Taiwan dedicated to the coral restoration scheme.

â€”â€”

About Delta 

Climate change is causing irreversible impacts. Coral reefs, known for their rich biodiversity and the capability to nourish a quarter of marine life, are at the forefront of the crisis. 

Also known as "tropical rainforests" in the sea, coral reefs have experienced fiveÂ massÂ bleachingÂ events in the past five years. Once global warming exceeds the 2ËšC thresholds, it's likely that 99% of coral reefs will die off worldwide.

In addition to launching a coral restoration initiative along the northeast coast of Taiwan, Delta Electronics Foundation collaborates with Asia University to host "Earth Pulsing: Nurturing Life Exhibition" and releases the first art NFT featuring coral restoration. Through these actions, we hope to evoke public awareness of ecological issues. 

For more information, please visit https://delta50.deltaww.com/initiative/sea.html

â€”â€”

Features
Iterations: 1 ~ 4
Tail: round, sharp
Feathering: yes, no
Color yes, no
Paper: normal, colored, white
Weight: regular, thin, bold
Special: -
Growth Speed: regular, slow, super slow

double click or press 's' to save as an image

metadata.name: PLANET ERROR #105
metadata.description:
The legendary collaboration between ippsketch and Piter Pasma.

Option: Put a hash with a number like #2 or #3 after the URL to render at double or triple the resolution!

metadata.name: Cloverfield #176
metadata.description:
"Nature is the source of all true knowledge".

Have you ever taken the time to look, deeply look, at all the details in a humble patch of grass ?

In this tiny microcosm, a constant, fierce battle is going on, day after day, plants reaching out for sun, down for access to soil, fighting for survival. Smaller grasses form groups, alliances making it harder for taller ones to take over. Dead leaves remind us that some of them lost the fight, fallen warriors who, soon enough, will be forgotten too. Growth, decay, life, death, the endless cycle, right in front of our eyes.

It is fascinating, and, for me at least, an endless source of inspiration.

It is my hope that, through this project, you will take the time to take a closer look at nature, and that, as the pale blue dot we call home keeps getting drier and drier, remember that even humble patches of grass should not be taken for granted.


Key commands:
's' - save as png
'b' - make the background transparent (for printing)
'1', '2, '4' - set the pixel density, for resolutions up to 8000x8000

This updated version of the project should render on mobile devices, albeit with slightly reduced quality. 
If you want to save the image for printing, I recommend you do so on desktop.

metadata.name: Lineage #161
metadata.description:
Lineage is a collaboration between Tim Maxwell and Twistie that attempts to bridge the gap between traditional and generative art.
256 outputs are generated using 100% JavaScript + p5js, written by Twistie, in the distinctive style of Tim Maxwell. The code tries to replicate not only the style, but also the process and inaccuracies that go into a drawing.

Each iteration has a unique title. 
All 256 rendered outputs and their respective titles will be displayed in high quality on https://twistie.org/lineage. 

10 lucky owners will have their iteration hand drawn and signed. They will each receive the physical 1/1 as well as an NFT version.

Press 's' on keyboard to save in high-res. This is how the art is intended to be viewed.

Hardware acceleration on Chromium-based browsers can impact performance!

metadata.name: The Restoration Scheme: Shape Observation #57
metadata.description:
â€œShape Observationâ€ is the first episode of â€œThe Restoration Schemeâ€ Series. The work was based on Staghorn Coral. 

Living on the land, we have few opportunities to see corals in real life.
Most of my impressions of corals come from photos and illustrations.
So I think the first person who discovers coral must be stunned by its shape and color.
They may paint hundreds of pictures like this.

â€”â€”

â€œThe Restoration Schemeâ€ Series

Itâ€™s a virtual action extended from the coral restoration plan led by Delta Electronics Foundation from Taiwan, consisting of five generative corals. Each of them was based on five different species of coral as the theme.

If collectors mint virtual corals, Delta Electronics Foundation will drop coral seedlings collectively in the sea. 

The project is powered by FAB DAO (Formosa Art Bank). The split will donate to the local organization from Taiwan dedicated to the coral restoration scheme.

â€”â€”

About Delta 

Climate change is causing irreversible impacts. Coral reefs, known for their rich biodiversity and the capability to nourish a quarter of marine life, are at the forefront of the crisis. 

Also known as "tropical rainforests" in the sea, coral reefs have experienced fiveÂ massÂ bleachingÂ events in the past five years. Once global warming exceeds the 2ËšC thresholds, it's likely that 99% of coral reefs will die off worldwide.

In addition to launching a coral restoration initiative along the northeast coast of Taiwan, Delta Electronics Foundation collaborates with Asia University to host "Earth Pulsing: Nurturing Life Exhibition" and releases the first art NFT featuring coral restoration. Through these actions, we hope to evoke public awareness of ecological issues. 

For more information, please visit https://delta50.deltaww.com/initiative/sea.html

â€”â€”

Features
Iterations: 1 ~ 4
Tail: round, sharp
Feathering: yes, no
Color yes, no
Paper: normal, colored, white
Weight: regular, thin, bold
Special: -
Growth Speed: regular, slow, super slow

double click or press 's' to save as an image

metadata.name: Ordinary Places #196
metadata.description:
â€œOrdinary Placesâ€ is a fully-coded meditation on the poetic beauty of everyday landscapes. 

The architectural characters in these landscapes include water towers (inspired by Bernd & Hilla Becherâ€™s â€œWater Towerâ€ photography series), gas stations (inspired by Ed Ruschaâ€™s â€œ26 Gasoline Stationsâ€ photography book), and barns (inspired by childhood memories on my grandfatherâ€™s farm). 

Yet, while these scenes may seem ordinary upon first glance, something darker lurks beneath the surface. The hidden secrets of these Ordinary Places can only be revealed through the minting process. In this sense, the outputs are not merely a collection individual scenes, but instead, a coherent world animated by shared themes and narratives.     

Pressing the down arrow saves the coded output as a .png image.

metadata.name: Movimento #16
metadata.description:
"No matter who you are, how many will accompany you, you always go somewhere even if that place is staying here. You move!" - Grandmaster of the storm

This artwork was created with p5.js

Collab: Nobody (@jorgemauro1000) and Eduxdux (@eduxdux_).

metadata.name: Hoppler #6
metadata.description:
Technological progress is always marked by how fast a vehicle moves, 
because humans love speed and that is why racing is one of the most famous sports in the world. 
But when the speed becomes too fast racing on earth means nothing anymore, 
where do we go next?

Two style of coloring
5 different zoom levels
Moon(4 kind)
Meteor(rare)
No stars background(rare)
